steps.title: Wash the olives well in water and place them in a big bowl which can hold all the olives and add water to cover them.
steps.content: Wash the olives well in water and place them in a big bowl which can hold all the olives and add water to cover them. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Extract the bitterness from the olives by soaking them in fresh water for a week.
steps.content: Extract the bitterness from the olives by soaking them in fresh water for a week. Change the water every day. You can split the olives by beating lightly (without crushing) every olive with a wood gavel. This will speed up the waiting time in the next steps. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Pour out the soaking water after seven days of soaking.
steps.content: Pour out the soaking water after seven days of soaking. Get a clean jar and stuff the olives inside. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Put in the garlic, hot peppers, lemon slices, coriander or fennel seeds and bay leaves into the jar.
steps.content: Put in the garlic, hot peppers, lemon slices, coriander or fennel seeds and bay leaves into the jar.

steps.title: Pour the salt solution into the jar until it covers the olives.
steps.content: Pour the salt solution into the jar until it covers the olives.

steps.title: Pour a bit of olive oil to create a thin protective layer on top.
steps.content: Pour a bit of olive oil to create a thin protective layer on top.

steps.title: Close the jar and place it in a cool, dark place.
steps.content: Close the jar and place it in a cool, dark place. [4] X Research source

steps.title: The olives will be ready for eating after 2 weeks to a month, if they were split, or four months if they are intact.
steps.content: The olives will be ready for eating after 2 weeks to a month, if they were split, or four months if they are intact. [5] X Research source
